facts.text: During the year 1948 the appellant made a profit of Rs. 11,97,648-11-9.
In 1948, appellant paid 24 3/4 per cent. dividend on ordinary shares, being the maximum under the Public Companies Limitation of Dividend Ordinance of 1948.
In 1948, appellant paid to the workers their full share of bonus at annas 4 in a rupee of their basic earnings.
During 1949, selling rates for cloth and yarn were controlled by Government and approximately 4 per cent. below those in 1948.
Basic wages increased from 1st December 1948 by order of Government of Uttar Pradesh, total wages higher than previous year.
Indiscipline amongst workers, production suffered; strike in October 1949, mills closed nearly a month.
Management unable to secure cotton, curtailment of working hours.
Appellant suffered trading loss of Rs. 5,02,563-1-10 in 1949.
Rs. 2,50,000 excess reserve for taxation written back; Rs. 10,01,871-13-5 transferred from investment account; aggregate Rs. 12,51,871-13-5 brought into balance-sheet.
After deducting trading loss, credit balance of Rs. 7,49,308-11-7 shown as profit for 1949; previous balance added, dividend of 24 3/4 per cent. paid.

Appellant paid ex gratia bonus to workmen at annas 2 per rupee of basic earnings; notification dated 7th April 1950 clarified it was discretionary, despite loss, not related to contract of employment.

On 4th May 1950, Secretary of respondent Union petitioned Provincial Conciliation Officer (Textile) claiming more production in 1949 than 1948, no reason profits less, bonus wrongly reduced; demanded annas 4 per rupee.
Industrial dispute referred to Regional Conciliation Board (Textile), Kanpur; majority awarded bonus at annas 4 per rupee.
Appellant appealed to Industrial Court (Textiles and Hosiery), Kanpur; accepted appellant's contention, allowed appeal, set aside award.

Respondent appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal; agreed with Industrial Court on facts (trading loss) and general law, but applied social justice as special case since capital had excess return, directed bonus annas 4 per rupee within six weeks.
Both Industrial Court and Labour Appellate Tribunal found trading loss of Rs. 5,02,563-1-10 in 1949 and dividend distributed after transferring Rs. 12,51,871-13-5 from reserves.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on 21st May 1951.

legal_issues.text: Whether the workers are entitled to the payment of a bonus in spite of the employer having worked at a loss during the year 1949.
Whether the workers have any right, title or interest in the reserves and the undistributed profits of the previous years.

petitioner_arguments.text: No basis or justification for demand for bonus if industrial concern resulted in loss that year; bonus not deferred wage; workers have no right in reserves or undistributed profits.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Millowners Association, Bombay v. Rashtreeya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay (1950 2 L.L.J. 247); formula of first charges on gross profits

respondent_arguments.text: More production in 1949 than 1948; no reason to hold profit less; bonus rate wrongly reduced; entitled to annas 4 per rupee.

court_reasoning.text: Primary meaning of bonus is a boon or gift over what is nominally due; secondary meaning in industrial relations as sharing surplus after prior charges.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bonus claim only if profits from joint contribution of capital and labour that year; no bonus if trading loss.

court_reasoning.text: Workers have no right, title or interest in reserves or undistributed profits; these belong to shareholders; labour force fluctuating, no continuity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transfer from reserves to pay dividend does not entitle workers to bonus when trading loss that year.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal's social justice consideration irrelevant and untenable; workers contributed to loss by indiscipline and strike.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Formula from Full Bench not applied; social justice not vague fancy of adjudicator.

court_reasoning.text: Article 136 allows interference if arbitrary or unfair deal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Supreme Court can review tribunal decisions.

holdings.text: If working results in trading loss, no profits available for bonus distribution.
Workers have no claim on reserves or undistributed profits of previous years for bonus.

precedents_cited.case_name: Millowners Association, Bombay v. Rashtreeya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Evolved formula for bonus: first charges on gross profits (depreciation, rehabilitation, return on capital), surplus for bonus.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nizam Sugar Factory Ltd., Hyderabad v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: No bonus if loss that year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Textile Mills, Madhya Pradesh v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: No bonus if loss; reiterated formula.

precedents_cited.case_name: Famous Cine Laboratory v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: No bonus if loss; social justice not individual fancy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi v. Employees of the Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Article 136 applies to industrial tribunals; interference if arbitrary.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhakeswari Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal

statutes_cited.name: Public Companies Limitation of Dividend Ordinance of 1948
Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Set up tribunals whose decisions reviewable under Article 136.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; decision of Labour Appellate Tribunal reversed; decision of Industrial Court (Textiles and Hosiery), Kanpur restored. No bonus payable for 1949.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of Industrial Court's order setting aside bonus award.

key_quotes.text: "A boon or gift over and above what is nominally due as remuneration to the receiver and which is therefore something wholly to the good."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Bonus is not a deferred wage. Because if it were so it would necessarily rank for precedence before dividends."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on nature of bonus.

key_quotes.text: "Social justice is a very vague and indeterminate expression and no clear-cut definition can be laid down which will cover all the situations."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejection of tribunal's social justice reasoning.
